item1.value:
Noninferirority of Low caps relative to All-caps
A decline in performance in older respondents

item2.value:
All caps is portrayed as a helpful intervention that improves consumer consent. If low-caps is non-inferior, this undermines this theory.
A negative effect on older readers would show that all-caps is actually harmful.

item11.value: Repeating the same exact study, in a different platform

item24.value: If I have fewer older readers (>55), it will weaken the effect of age, so given the sample size, I'd expect a similar sign but a weaker effect.

item27.value: Same as original, but expecting less effect

item28.value:
Same sign for older readers, but with a weaker effect size
AC/LC: It may be more difficult to prove non-inferiority within a 10% margin, but I expect very similar results in both AC/LC (potentially slightly negative for AC). Any significant improvement in AC would count as a surprise.

attributes.title: Replication Study on the Mediating Effect of Work Engagement between Self-efficacy and Job Satisfaction
attributes.description: Replication on the premise of master's thesis

q1.value: Replication Study on the Mediating Effect of Work Engagement between Self-efficacy and Job Satisfaction

q3.value:
The purpose of this study is the replication of the model and study by Orgambídez, Borrego, and Vázquez-Aguado (2020) “Linking Self-efficacy to Quality of Working Life: The Role of Work Engagement”. This study is conducted in fulfillment of our master thesis (Spring semester 2020).
The reason for this replication is to test the applicability  of their proposed model and findings in a different work field as well as culture, in order to determine if the main principles, which are derived from the job demands and resources model (JD-R), hold true in different occupational fields. According to the main idea of the usability of JD-R is that it can be applied to any work field.  
The original study was conducted in Spain with nurses in a cross-sectional correlational investigation. This replication study, on the other hand, will take place in Sweden in companies where the structure of work is focused on IT, software and technology. 

Research question: The impact of self-efficacy (IV) on employees’ job satisfaction (DV)  with a mediating effect of work engagement between the independent variable and the dependent variable.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Self-efficacy is positively related to job satisfaction.

Hypothesis 2: Self-efficacy is positively related to work engagement.

Hypothesis 3: Work engagement is positively related to job satisfaction.

Hypothesis 4: The positive relation between self-efficacy and job satisfaction is mediated by work engagement.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A cross-sectional correlational study will be conducted to test the relationship between self-efficacy (independent variable) and job satisfaction (dependent variable) as well as the mediating effect of work engagement between the independent and the dependent variables.

q9.value: No randomization will take place prior to the data collection or group formation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A survey study will be conducted, where employees from at least three different companies in Sweden will be asked to voluntarily participate in the study. The questionnaires will be distributed in a web-based form directly to the employees of the companies that participate in the study through their head managers or through HR departments.
The aim is to start the data collection in the last week of February 2020 or at the beginning of March 2020. The companies of focus operate in the South of  Sweden.  
Depending on the response rate, additional companies and regions may be added to fulfill the aimed sample size.

q13.value: Based on the principle of the analysis, the aim is to reach between 200-230 participants in order to achieve the minimum acceptable number for each variable in the instruments for the statistical analysis.

q14.value:
Based on the main analysis, that of path analysis, a minimum of five participants needs to be included for each variable of our measurements. In this study, 39 items will be used which means that the minimum sample size will have to include around 200 participants. 
Hoe (2008) suggets that in order to provide an adequate statistical power to either path analysis or structural equation model (SEM) then at least 200 or more participants are mandatory. 
The aim is to reach at least 230 - 250 with the purpose of increasing of power to ensure the stability of the correlations in the proposed model. 
Furthermore, as supported by Schönbrodtb and Perguini (2013), the larger the sample size is, the greater stability the sample size correlations will have. According to them, in order to reach the necessary point of stability (POS) where only minor variations from the true value occur, then the sample must be greater than n=161.

q15.value: The maximum sample size goal is that of n=230 - 250 to be reached by the 31st of March 2020. However, if this number hasn't been reached by then, the data collection period may have to be extended. The decision to continue or not will be made before any data is entered into a spreadsheet.

question.value:
Self- efficacy is measured with The Swedish General Self-Efficacy Scale (S-GSE) which is originally from Schwarzer and Jerusalem (1995) and translated in Swedish by Koskinen et al. (1999). The scale is comprised of 10 items with a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (Not at all true) to 4 (Exactly true). 

Work engagement is measured with the short version of the Utrecht Work Engagement Scale by Schaufeli and Bakker and Salanova (2003). The scale consists of 9 items with a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (Never) to 6 (Every day). 

Job Satisfaction is measured with the short form of the Minnesota Satisfaction Questionnaire (MSQ) created by Weiss et al. (1977). The translation into Swedish was made by Nystedt (1993; 1994 ). The scale consists of 20 items with a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (Very satisfied) to 5 (Very dissatisfied). 

Three demographical items will also be included and they will be in a separate sheet to ensure anonymity and those will not  be included with the rest of the raw data, after the data collection. 
Age and years of work experience will be asked to be answered with the exact value, whereas gender will be in a multiple-choice form (female, male and other).

Confirmatory Factor Analysis will be conducted to test the three measurements and to confirm if the structure of the model and the correlations among the variables hold true (to confirm the three-factor solution): 
Self-efficacy (10 items), work engagement (9 items) job satisfaction (20 items).

To test the fit of the model we will use the following indices: Tucker- Luis Index (TLI), comparative fit index (CFI), standardized root mean square residual (SRMR) and mean square error of approximation (RMSEA).

For the testing of the mediation model, path analysis will be used to investigate the chain of the predictor variable (self-efficacy) towards the mediating variable (work engagement) which is supposed to lead to the resulting variables (job satisfaction and affective organizational commitment). 
To measure the association between the the contiunues variables, based on the hypotheses H1, H2, and H3 Pearson's correlation coefficient (r) will be used. 
Chronbach's alpha will also be calculated to test the reliability of the measurements. 

SPSS Amos 26 and JASP are considered be used for the analysis of the statistical model.

q20.value: Depending on the items of the scales that will be used, some of the items may need to reversed (R). This will be done with the transformation and the recording process of the items.

q21.value:
As fit indices  for the confirmatory factor analysis, the Tucker–Lewis index (TLI) and the comparative fit index (CFI) will be used and they should be above .90. The standardized root mean square residual (SRMR), as well as the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), should be below .08.
The significance alpha level (a) for the testing of the hypotheses will be .05 with a one-tailed test.

q22.value:
As a pre-measure we will ensure that the subjects' scores in order to be used in the statistical analysis they have responded the items of each scale. 
To identify outliers, standardized z-scores cut off values will be used, as they can indicate the deviations from the mean scores of the sample. Outliers will be used in the analysis.

q23.value: In the cases where not all four indices are completed then the subjects will be excluded from the study. More specifically, it depends on the percentage of the missing data. In the case that the data missing from one scale is less than 10%, then the replacement for that missing data will be conducted with the average scores the particpants has on a specific scale.

q24.value: In terms of exploratory analysis structural equation model  (SEM) is considered as a further means of the investigation if the possibility to further explore this study arises in the future.  This is due to the fact that for this study the time available is very limited to allow to delve into SEM analysis.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Does drunkorexia only affect young adults? Alcoholimia in a general adult population

other.value:
Should we have sufficient number of non-binary participants to ensure reasonable statistical power, we will run the primary regression analysis in that population.

Risky drinking habits (measured by the AUDIT) might only lead to alcoholimia if someone also has high levels of weight concerns (measured by the EAT-26). Similarly, excessive exercise (measured by the IPAQ) might only lead to alcoholimia if someone has high levels of weight concern (measured by the RRS-concern for dieting subscale). We will assess these possibilities using exploratory moderation analyses. The exact variables in these analyses will be informed by the predictors that are significant in the regression analyses.

We will assess whether people perform alcoholimia behaviours for financial reasons using a single item question directly after the ICB-WGA scale. We will ask “Have you ever performed any of the above behaviours before drinking alcohol (skipped a meal, ate less, restricted your eating, engaged in strenuous exercise) for financial reasons? For example, you might have skipped dinner to have more money to spend on alcohol, or restricted food intake to get drunk faster and reduce the money spent on alcohol.” [YES/NO/NA I have not performed the above behaviours before drinking alcohol]

sample.value: We will recruit US participants via Amazon Mechanical Turk. We are restricting our sample to US residents to reduce the possibility that nationality will affect drinking behaviour. Our target sample size is 250 useable participants, calculated using an a priori G*Power analysis (linear multiple regression fixed model, R squared deviation from zero). We are interested in having enough participants to detect a medium effect size (R squared = .15) or larger. With six predictor variables, R squared = .15 (f squared = .17), alpha = .05, and power = .95 we need 125 participants. Due to wanting to run the regression twice, once for males and once for females, we have doubled the sample size to N = 250.

analyses.value:
To determine the prevalence of alcoholimia symptoms in a general adult population, we will report descriptive statistics for the CEBRACS (by subscale and total score) and ICB-WGA (total score only).  

We will run an initial bivariate correlation analysis to determine whether age correlates with total CEBRACS score. If age correlates significantly, we will include age as a continuous variable in the regression. We will check the correlations for all other independent variables with the total CEBRACS score prior to conducting our linear regressions. Variables will also be checked for multicollinearity. 

We will then run a stepwise linear regression to assess how age, drinking habits (AUDIT scores and/or binge drinking item), drinking for coping purposes (DMQ-coping subscale), abnormal eating behaviours and weight concerns (EAT-26), dietary restraint (RRS-concern for dieting subscale), and exercising for appearance purposes (MPAM-appearance subscale) affect total CEBRACS scores. We will investigate how these variables affect different symptom types using the CEBRACS subscales as dependent variables. To ensure our results generalise across alcoholimia measures, we will re-run the regression using scores on the ICB-WGA as the dependent variable. 

To determine how different components of eating disorder psychopathology affect alcoholimia symptoms we will run a secondary regression using the EPSI subscales (in particular body dissatisfaction, binge eating, cognitive restraint, purging, restricting, and excessive exercise) and AUDIT scores as independent variables (as in Hunt & Forbush, 2016). 

To establish whether gender affects alcoholimia, we will run an independent samples t-test on overall symptoms (CEBRACS and ICB-WGA) and symptom subscales (CEBRACS only). It is possible that gender could change which factors predict alcoholimia. For example, dietary restraint may be a stronger predictor of alcoholimia symptoms than drinking habits for females, while drinking habits may be a stronger predictor than dietary restraint for males.  To assess these possibilities, we will run the same regressions as above but separately for males and females.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who report that they have not drunk alcohol in the past 30 days. These participants will not complete the remainder of the survey but will be paid for their time. We have opted not to include “drinking in the past 30 days” as a selection criteria to avoid getting a biased sample. Among participants who finish the survey, we will exclude those who fail all three attention checks, do not complete the alcoholimia measures, or appear to be randomly responding.

dependent.value: We will assess alcoholimia using two questionnaires. The Compensatory Eating and Behaviors in Response to Alcohol Scale (CEBRACS; Rahal, Bryant, Darkes, Menzel, & Thompson, 2012) is a widely used reliable measure of how often people engaged in alcoholimia behaviours in the past three months. Notably, as well as being totalled, scores can be grouped by symptom type (alcohol effects, bulimia, diet and exercise, restriction) and time point (i.e., behaviours performed before, during, and after consuming alcohol). We will supplement the CEBRACS with the Inappropriate Compensatory Behaviours to Avoid Weight Gain from Alcohol scale (ICB-WGA; Hunt & Forbush, 2016). In the ICB-WGA, participants rate the frequency with which they engaged in five types of alcoholimia behaviours (e.g., skipping meals to counteract calories) over the past month. These items are summed for a total ICB-WGA score.

conditions.value: There are no conditions. Participants will complete all scales in a random order.

hypothesis.value:
A disturbing percentage of people restrict their food intake, excessively exercise, or purge to compensate for the calories gained from drinking alcohol, or to enhance the effects of alcohol (e.g., Barry & Piazza-Gardner, 2012). For example, 58% of an Australian university sample (Knight, Castelnuovo, Pietrabissa, Manzoni, & Simpson, 2016) and 39% of a US college sample (Giles, Champion, Sutfin, McCoy, & Wagoner, 2009) reported performing these compensatory behaviours before, during, or after consuming alcohol. First identified and termed “drunkorexia” by popular media (see Chambers, 2008), these behaviours have since been formally termed “food and alcohol disturbance” (Choquette, Rancourt, & Thompson, 2018) or “alcoholimia” (Thompson-Memmer, Glassman, & Diehr, 2019)—the term we will use. There is currently a push to formally recognise alcoholimia as a subtype of Other Specified Feeding and Eating Disorders (OSFED) in the DSM-5, because of its association with both disordered eating and substance abuse (Thompson-Memmer et al., 2019). But, before such formal recognition can occur, we need to determine if alcoholimia occurs in a general adult population, beyond young adulthood (i.e., 18-25 years). 

The view that alcoholimia only affects young adults is partly attributable to exclusively studying alcoholimia in young adults. Of the 26 empirical alcoholimia studies, 22 used university samples (e.g., Knight et al., 2016), two used adolescents/high school students (e.g.,  Sclissel & Skeer, 2015), and two used young adults (not just college students, e.g., Lupi et al., 2017). The oldest mean age of these samples is 22 years (Lupi et al., 2017), demonstrating a clear gap in our understanding of the prevalence of alcoholimia. 

There are three key reasons to believe that alcoholimia occurs beyond young adulthood. First, people do not stop drinking when they leave university or turn 26 years old. The percentage of current alcohol users—i.e., drinking at least once in the past 30 days—is similar among American adults aged 18-25 years (55.1%) and 26 years or over (55.3%) (Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration [SAMHSA], 2019). Although rates of binge drinking are higher among younger (34.9%) than older (25.1%) adults (SAMHSA, 2019), a quarter of adults over 26 years continuing to binge drink is not a negligible proportion. Second, behaviours developed between 18 and 25 years continue and are solidified during adulthood (Williams, Holmbeck, & Greenley, 2002). By this logic, if people practice alcoholimic behaviours during young adulthood, they are likely to continue practicing these behaviours into older adulthood. Third, there is a well-supported positive association between alcohol consumption and physical activity which occurs across adulthood (e.g., French, Popovici, & Maclean, 2009). Given excessively exercising to compensate for drinking is a symptom of alcoholimia, the existence of this association in college and adult samples alike supports the view that alcoholimia occurs beyond young adulthood. 

We have two primary aims: (1) to establish the rates of alcoholimia in a general adult population who drank alcohol at least once in the past 30 days, and (2) to determine whether there are gender differences in alcoholimia rates in an adult sample. Some studies suggest that alcoholimia is more prevalent in women than men, due to women’s increased body dissatisfaction and weight control motivation (Barry & Piazza-Gardner, 2012; Eisenberg & Fitz, 2014; Rahal et al., 2012). But men might engage in alcoholimic behaviours more often than women, simply because men are more likely to drink at risky levels than women (NIHW, 2017). Indeed, other studies find no gender differences in the occurrence of alcoholimia (e.g., Burke, Cremeens, & Vail-Smith, 2010). Recent work by Gorrell, Walker, Anderson, and Boswell (2019) sheds light on these mixed findings, suggesting gender differences in alcoholimia are driven by women being more likely than men to display purging symptoms, but not restricting, physical activity, or overall alcoholimia symptoms.

As a secondary aim, we are interested in determining what factors moderate alcoholimia symptoms in a general adult population. Thus, we will measure BMI, drinking habits (via the AUDIT: Babor, Higgins-Biddle, Saunders, & Monteiro, 2001; Saunders & Aasland, 1987), motivations for drinking alcohol (via the DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994), abnormal eating behaviours and weight concerns (via the EAT-26; Garner, Olmstead, Bohr, & Garfinkel, 1982), eating disorder psychopathology (via the EPSI; Forbush et al., 2013), restrained eating (via the RRS; Herman & Polivy, 1980), physical activity levels (via the IPAQ; Booth et al., 2003), and motivations for exercising (via the MPAM-R; Ryan, Frederick, Lepes, Rubio, & Sheldon, 1997)

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

These participants will not complete the remainder of the survey but will be paid for their time. We have opted not to include “drinking in the past 30 days” as a selection criteria to avoid getting a biased sample. Among participants who finish the survey, we will exclude those who fail all three attention checks, do not complete the alcoholimia measures, or appear to be randomly responding.
registration_responses.dependent: We will assess alcoholimia using two questionnaires. The Compensatory Eating and Behaviors in Response to Alcohol Scale (CEBRACS; Rahal, Bryant, Darkes, Menzel, & Thompson, 2012) is a widely used reliable measure of how often people engaged in alcoholimia behaviours in the past three months. Notably, as well as being totalled, scores can be grouped by symptom type (alcohol effects, bulimia, diet and exercise, restriction) and time point (i.e., behaviours performed before, during, and after consuming alcohol). We will supplement the CEBRACS with the Inappropriate Compensatory Behaviours to Avoid Weight Gain from Alcohol scale (ICB-WGA; Hunt & Forbush, 2016). In the ICB-WGA, participants rate the frequency with which they engaged in five types of alcoholimia behaviours (e.g., skipping meals to counteract calories) over the past month. These items are summed for a total ICB-WGA score.
registration_responses.conditions: There are no conditions. Participants will complete all scales in a random order.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
A disturbing percentage of people restrict their food intake, excessively exercise, or purge to compensate for the calories gained from drinking alcohol, or to enhance the effects of alcohol (e.g., Barry & Piazza-Gardner, 2012). For example, 58% of an Australian university sample (Knight, Castelnuovo, Pietrabissa, Manzoni, & Simpson, 2016) and 39% of a US college sample (Giles, Champion, Sutfin, McCoy, & Wagoner, 2009) reported performing these compensatory behaviours before, during, or after consuming alcohol. First identified and termed “drunkorexia” by popular media (see Chambers, 2008), these behaviours have since been formally termed “food and alcohol disturbance” (Choquette, Rancourt, & Thompson, 2018) or “alcoholimia” (Thompson-Memmer, Glassman, & Diehr, 2019)—the term we will use. There is currently a push to formally recognise alcoholimia as a subtype of Other Specified Feeding and Eating Disorders (OSFED) in the DSM-5, because of its association with both disordered eating and substance abuse (Thompson-Memmer et al., 2019). But, before such formal recognition can occur, we need to determine if alcoholimia occurs in a general adult population, beyond young adulthood (i.e., 18-25 years). 

The view that alcoholimia only affects young adults is partly attributable to exclusively studying alcoholimia in young adults. Of the 26 empirical alcoholimia studies, 22 used university samples (e.g., Knight et al., 2016), two used adolescents/high school students (e.g.,  Sclissel & Skeer, 2015), and two used young adults (not just college students, e.g., Lupi et al., 2017). The oldest mean age of these samples is 22 years (Lupi et al., 2017), demonstrating a clear gap in our understanding of the prevalence of alcoholimia. 

There are three key reasons to believe that alcoholimia occurs beyond young adulthood. First, people do not stop drinking when they leave university or turn 26 years old. The percentage of current alcohol users—i.e., drinking at least once in the past 30 days—is similar among American adults aged 18-25 years (55.1%) and 26 years or over (55.3%) (Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration [SAMHSA], 2019). Although rates of binge drinking are higher among younger (34.9%) than older (25.1%) adults (SAMHSA, 2019), a quarter of adults over 26 years continuing to binge drink is not a negligible proportion. Second, behaviours developed between 18 and 25 years continue and are solidified during adulthood (Williams, Holmbeck, & Greenley, 2002). By this logic, if people practice alcoholimic behaviours during young adulthood, they are likely to continue practicing these behaviours into older adulthood. Third, there is a well-supported positive association between alcohol consumption and physical activity which occurs across adulthood (e.g., French, Popovici, & Maclean, 2009). Given excessively exercising to compensate for drinking is a symptom of alcoholimia, the existence of this association in college and adult samples alike supports the view that alcoholimia occurs beyond young adulthood. 

We have two primary aims: (1) to establish the rates of alcoholimia in a general adult population who drank alcohol at least once in the past 30 days, and (2) to determine whether there are gender differences in alcoholimia rates in an adult sample. Some studies suggest that alcoholimia is more prevalent in women than men, due to women’s increased body dissatisfaction and weight control motivation (Barry & Piazza-Gardner, 2012; Eisenberg & Fitz, 2014; Rahal et al., 2012). But men might engage in alcoholimic behaviours more often than women, simply because men are more likely to drink at risky levels than women (NIHW, 2017). Indeed, other studies find no gender differences in the occurrence of alcoholimia (e.g., Burke, Cremeens, & Vail-Smith, 2010). Recent work by Gorrell, Walker, Anderson, and Boswell (2019) sheds light on these mixed findings, suggesting gender differences in alcoholimia are driven by women being more likely than men to display purging symptoms, but not restricting, physical activity, or overall alcoholimia symptoms.

As a secondary aim, we are interested in determining what factors moderate alcoholimia symptoms in a general adult population. Thus, we will measure BMI, drinking habits (via the AUDIT: Babor, Higgins-Biddle, Saunders, & Monteiro, 2001; Saunders & Aasland, 1987), motivations for drinking alcohol (via the DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994), abnormal eating behaviours and weight concerns (via the EAT-26; Garner, Olmstead, Bohr, & Garfinkel, 1982), eating disorder psychopathology (via the EPSI; Forbush et al., 2013), restrained eating (via the RRS; Herman & Polivy, 1980), physical activity levels (via the IPAQ; Booth et al., 2003), and motivations for exercising (via the MPAM-R; Ryan, Frederick, Lepes, Rubio, & Sheldon, 1997)
